title: How to Cook Ugu Soup

steps.headline: Wash off the leaves.
steps.description: Run the leaves under cold water from your faucet. This will remove any grit, dirt, or pesticides that may be left over on the leaves. Pat the leaves dry with paper towels before moving onto the next step. If you don’t rinse the leaves, your soup may taste gritty or sandy.

steps.headline: Cut off hard stems and flowers from the leaves.
steps.description: The flowers on the pumpkin leaves taste bitter and the stems are hard an inedible. Use a sharp kitchen knife or kitchen shears to strip the leaves bare.

steps.headline: Dice the pumpkin leaves.
steps.description: Line the leaves up on a cutting board or flat surface and cut the leaves into 1 by 1 inch (2.5 cm × 2.5 cm) pieces. Set the leaves aside and move onto the next step. Be careful when cutting the leaves so that you don't cut yourself.

steps.headline: Boil the leaves for 2-3 minutes.
steps.description: Fill a pot with water and place it on your stovetop. Turn the burner to high and wait for bubbles to form on the top of the water. Then, add the pumpkin leaves to the pot. Blanching the pumpkin leaves will remove the bitter taste from them.

steps.headline: Place the leaves in an ice bath.
steps.description: Prepare a bowl with water and ice cubes as your leaves are boiling. After they boil for 1-2 minutes, use a pair of tongs to immediately transport the leaves from the boiling water to an ice bath to stop the cooking process. Leaving the leaves in the hot water could overcook them and cause them to be mushy.

steps.headline: Pat the leaves dry with paper towels.
steps.description: Remove as much water from the leaves as you can before setting them aside. They are now blanched and prepared to be incorporated into the soup. The leaves should still be somewhat firm.

steps.headline: Place your proteins in a large stockpot.
steps.description: Find a pot with a lid that’s able to hold at least 10 cups (2,400 ml) of liquid. Place the protein of your choice in the pot and place it on the stovetop. Remove all bones from the protein before you cook it. Chicken will create a lighter, clearer stock than beef.

steps.headline: Add 3 cups (710 ml) of water to the pot.
steps.description: Measure out 3 cups (710 ml) of water with a measuring cup and pour it over the protein. Season the water with a pinch of salt. You will later use the protein in the soup itself, so leave it in the stock.

steps.headline: Cook the stock on medium heat for 25 minutes.
steps.description: Put a lid on top of the pot and stir the stock every 5-7 minutes. As the fat from the protein rises to the top of the soup, scrape it off with a spoon and dispose of it. The water will start to cook the protein and incorporate the flavor of the meat to the stock.

steps.headline: Add your stockfish to the pot and cook it for another 5 minutes.
steps.description: Continue cooking the stock on medium heat while stirring it. Once you’re done, you can prepare the rest of the soup or you store the stock in the freezer or refrigerator. You can store ugu stock in the refrigerator for 3-4 days or in the freezer for up to 4 months. Stockfish are dried unsalted fish.

steps.headline: Toast peanuts in a saucepan.
steps.description: Take the 8 ounces (230 g) of skinless peanuts and put them in a dry pan. Turn the heat to medium-high and stir the nuts for 1-2 minutes. They should start to brown and let off a toasty fragrance. Do not cook the peanuts for more than 2 minutes because they are very easy to burn.

steps.headline: Blend peanuts, 4 cloves of garlic, and half of an onion together.
steps.description: Place the ingredients in a food processor. Pulse the ingredients together until they form a powder. Make sure that the lid is on tight before you turn the food processor on.

steps.headline: Fry onions in a pot for 2 minutes.
steps.description: Place 1 tablespoon (15 ml) of olive oil into the pot and turn the heat to medium. Wait 1-2 minutes for the oil to heat up before adding the onions to the pot. Cook the onions for 2 minutes, or until transparent and fragrant. The onions should sizzle when they hit the pan.

steps.headline: Add crayfish, tomatoes, protein, and 1 cup (240 ml) of stock to the pot.
steps.description: Mix the ingredients together after you add them to the pot. Let the soup simmer for 5 minutes before moving onto the next step.

steps.headline: Add the peanut mixture and 2 cups (470 ml) of stock to the pan.
steps.description: Add the last 2 cups (470 ml) of stock to the pan after adding the powder. Continue to mix the soup together with a wooden spoon. The dry peanut and onion mixture will thicken up the soup.

steps.headline: Add pumpkin leaves and let the soup simmer for another 10 minutes.
steps.description: Once the soup is cooked enough, it should be fragrant and the pumpkin leaves should be soft. You can serve the soup hot, or store it in your refrigerator for 3-4 days. Ugu soup is often served with a side of plantains. You can freeze ugu soup for up to 4 months.

text: Blanching the Pumpkin Leaves Wash off the leaves. Run the leaves under cold water from your faucet. This will remove any grit, dirt, or pesticides that may be left over on the leaves. Pat the leaves dry with paper towels before moving onto the next step. If you don’t rinse the leaves, your soup may taste gritty or sandy. Cut off hard stems and flowers from the leaves. The flowers on the pumpkin leaves taste bitter and the stems are hard an inedible. Use a sharp kitchen knife or kitchen shears to strip the leaves bare. Dice the pumpkin leaves. Line the leaves up on a cutting board or flat surface and cut the leaves into 1 by 1 inch (2.5 cm × 2.5 cm) pieces. Set the leaves aside and move onto the next step. Be careful when cutting the leaves so that you don't cut yourself. Boil the leaves for 2-3 minutes. Fill a pot with water and place it on your stovetop. Turn the burner to high and wait for bubbles to form on the top of the water. Then, add the pumpkin leaves to the pot. Blanching the pumpkin leaves will remove the bitter taste from them. Place the leaves in an ice bath. Prepare a bowl with water and ice cubes as your leaves are boiling. After they boil for 1-2 minutes, use a pair of tongs to immediately transport the leaves from the boiling water to an ice bath to stop the cooking process. Leaving the leaves in the hot water could overcook them and cause them to be mushy. Pat the leaves dry with paper towels. Remove as much water from the leaves as you can before setting them aside. They are now blanched and prepared to be incorporated into the soup. The leaves should still be somewhat firm. Making Ugu Stock Place your proteins in a large stockpot. Find a pot with a lid that’s able to hold at least 10 cups (2,400 ml) of liquid. Place the protein of your choice in the pot and place it on the stovetop. Remove all bones from the protein before you cook it. Chicken will create a lighter, clearer stock than beef. Add 3 cups (710 ml) of water to the pot. Measure out 3 cups (710 ml) of water with a measuring cup and pour it over the protein. Season the water with a pinch of salt. You will later use the protein in the soup itself, so leave it in the stock. Cook the stock on medium heat for 25 minutes. Put a lid on top of the pot and stir the stock every 5-7 minutes. As the fat from the protein rises to the top of the soup, scrape it off with a spoon and dispose of it. The water will start to cook the protein and incorporate the flavor of the meat to the stock. Add your stockfish to the pot and cook it for another 5 minutes. Continue cooking the stock on medium heat while stirring it. Once you’re done, you can prepare the rest of the soup or you store the stock in the freezer or refrigerator. You can store ugu stock in the refrigerator for 3-4 days or in the freezer for up to 4 months. Stockfish are dried unsalted fish. Preparing Ugu Soup Toast peanuts in a saucepan. Take the 8 ounces (230 g) of skinless peanuts and put them in a dry pan. Turn the heat to medium-high and stir the nuts for 1-2 minutes. They should start to brown and let off a toasty fragrance. Do not cook the peanuts for more than 2 minutes because they are very easy to burn. Blend peanuts, 4 cloves of garlic, and half of an onion together. Place the ingredients in a food processor. Pulse the ingredients together until they form a powder. Make sure that the lid is on tight before you turn the food processor on. Fry onions in a pot for 2 minutes. Place 1 tablespoon (15 ml) of olive oil into the pot and turn the heat to medium. Wait 1-2 minutes for the oil to heat up before adding the onions to the pot. Cook the onions for 2 minutes, or until transparent and fragrant. The onions should sizzle when they hit the pan. Add crayfish, tomatoes, protein, and 1 cup (240 ml) of stock to the pot. Mix the ingredients together after you add them to the pot. Let the soup simmer for 5 minutes before moving onto the next step. Add the peanut mixture and 2 cups (470 ml) of stock to the pan. Add the last 2 cups (470 ml) of stock to the pan after adding the powder. Continue to mix the soup together with a wooden spoon. The dry peanut and onion mixture will thicken up the soup. Add pumpkin leaves and let the soup simmer for another 10 minutes. Once the soup is cooked enough, it should be fragrant and the pumpkin leaves should be soft. You can serve the soup hot, or store it in your refrigerator for 3-4 days. Ugu soup is often served with a side of plantains. You can freeze ugu soup for up to 4 months.
sentences: Blanching the Pumpkin Leaves Wash off the leaves.
Run the leaves under cold water from your faucet.
This will remove any grit, dirt, or pesticides that may be left over on the leaves.
Pat the leaves dry with paper towels before moving onto the next step.
If you don’t rinse the leaves, your soup may taste gritty or sandy.
Cut off hard stems and flowers from the leaves.
The flowers on the pumpkin leaves taste bitter and the stems are hard an inedible.
Use a sharp kitchen knife or kitchen shears to strip the leaves bare.
Dice the pumpkin leaves.
Line the leaves up on a cutting board or flat surface and cut the leaves into 1 by 1 inch (2.5 cm × 2.5 cm) pieces.
Set the leaves aside and move onto the next step.
Be careful when cutting the leaves so that you don't cut yourself.
Boil the leaves for 2-3 minutes.
Fill a pot with water and place it on your stovetop.
Turn the burner to high and wait for bubbles to form on the top of the water.
Then, add the pumpkin leaves to the pot.
Blanching the pumpkin leaves will remove the bitter taste from them.
Place the leaves in an ice bath.
Prepare a bowl with water and ice cubes as your leaves are boiling.
After they boil for 1-2 minutes, use a pair of tongs to immediately transport the leaves from the boiling water to an ice bath to stop the cooking process.
Leaving the leaves in the hot water could overcook them and cause them to be mushy.
Pat the leaves dry with paper towels.
Remove as much water from the leaves as you can before setting them aside.
They are now blanched and prepared to be incorporated into the soup.
The leaves should still be somewhat firm.
Making Ugu Stock Place your proteins in a large stockpot.
Find a pot with a lid that’s able to hold at least 10 cups (2,400 ml) of liquid.
Place the protein of your choice in the pot and place it on the stovetop.
Remove all bones from the protein before you cook it.
Chicken will create a lighter, clearer stock than beef.
Add 3 cups (710 ml) of water to the pot.
Measure out 3 cups (710 ml) of water with a measuring cup and pour it over the protein.
Season the water with a pinch of salt.
You will later use the protein in the soup itself, so leave it in the stock.
Cook the stock on medium heat for 25 minutes.
Put a lid on top of the pot and stir the stock every 5-7 minutes.
As the fat from the protein rises to the top of the soup, scrape it off with a spoon and dispose of it.
The water will start to cook the protein and incorporate the flavor of the meat to the stock.
Add your stockfish to the pot and cook it for another 5 minutes.
Continue cooking the stock on medium heat while stirring it.
Once you’re done, you can prepare the rest of the soup or you store the stock in the freezer or refrigerator.
You can store ugu stock in the refrigerator for 3-4 days or in the freezer for up to 4 months.
Stockfish are dried unsalted fish.
Preparing Ugu Soup Toast peanuts in a saucepan.
Take the 8 ounces (230 g) of skinless peanuts and put them in a dry pan.
Turn the heat to medium-high and stir the nuts for 1-2 minutes.
They should start to brown and let off a toasty fragrance.
Do not cook the peanuts for more than 2 minutes because they are very easy to burn.
Blend peanuts, 4 cloves of garlic, and half of an onion together.
Place the ingredients in a food processor.
Pulse the ingredients together until they form a powder.
Make sure that the lid is on tight before you turn the food processor on.
Fry onions in a pot for 2 minutes.
Place 1 tablespoon (15 ml) of olive oil into the pot and turn the heat to medium.
Wait 1-2 minutes for the oil to heat up before adding the onions to the pot.
Cook the onions for 2 minutes, or until transparent and fragrant.
The onions should sizzle when they hit the pan.
Add crayfish, tomatoes, protein, and 1 cup (240 ml) of stock to the pot.
Mix the ingredients together after you add them to the pot.
Let the soup simmer for 5 minutes before moving onto the next step.
Add the peanut mixture and 2 cups (470 ml) of stock to the pan.
Add the last 2 cups (470 ml) of stock to the pan after adding the powder.
Continue to mix the soup together with a wooden spoon.
The dry peanut and onion mixture will thicken up the soup.
Add pumpkin leaves and let the soup simmer for another 10 minutes.
Once the soup is cooked enough, it should be fragrant and the pumpkin leaves should be soft.
You can serve the soup hot, or store it in your refrigerator for 3-4 days.
Ugu soup is often served with a side of plantains.
You can freeze ugu soup for up to 4 months.
